review: This is a heads up/warning for anyone considering buying the Stick. The design or firmware is seriously flawed. As of today there are 224 posts on the customer discussions page (http://www.amazon.com/gp/r.html?http://www.amazon.com/forum/kindle/ref=cm_cd_pg_pg1?_encoding=UTF8&cdForum;=Fx1D7SY3BVSESG&cdPage;=1&cdThread;=Tx2CDOG0K31UBSB), all complaining about the Stick's inability to maintain a network connection. Amazon may fix the problems and soon, because if they don't, they will have a failed product on their hands. I suggest that if you're interested in getting one, WAIT until you hear that the problems have been fixed.BTW, when it works right, it's glorious and the content is enormous (200,000+ movies/videos/etc.), much of it free to Prime members.****************Update 7/2/15: I became so frustrated with the Stick's inability to maintain a network connection (despite System/Settings saying the connection was "VERY GOOD" and "Connected"... not "Connected with problems". . . "Connected") that I e-mailed Jeff Bezos about the Stick's problems. This eventually led to Amazon sending 4 tech support engineers from Sunnyvale to my home in Delaware on May 1. They spent 4.5 hours taking spectrum measurements and trying numerous things. When they left, they had made only 2 changes: (1) Moved the Stick to HDMI 1 and my DVR to HDMI 4, thereby separating the 2 connections by the maximum distance, presumably to minimize electronic "noise" close to the Stick. (2) They left me with a new Netgear 802.11ac router (thank you!) and put the Stick on its 5GHz signal (the D-Link N router I had only provided a 2.4GHz signal). Since May 1, the Stick has worked FLAWLESSLY.The question is, which of those 2 changes had the most to do with the Stick's now perfect performance? IMO, it is the 5GHz signal. The Stick remains subject to interference from other devices in and around my home. Most of them...probably all of them...send out 2.4GHz signals. By moving the Stick to a 5GHz signal, most if not all of the interference is of no concern. THAT DOES NOT SOLVE THE STICK'S PROBLEM; it's just a workaround to avoid its inability to reject stray signals. Amazon still needs to redesign it so it performs like Google's Chromecast, ROKU sticks, etc. Until that's done, many people will have problems with it.
author: DKT "Don"
